Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the significance of Governor Christie's failure to have his party win control of at least one legislative body by stating that he is the only governor since World War II to do so.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that Governor Christie is the only governor since World War II to fail in having his party win control of at least one legislative body.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the ability to have one's party win control of a legislative body is a measure of effectiveness or success as a governor, which may be a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for Governor Christie's failure to have his party win control, such as political dynamics, opposition strength, or other external factors.
